conclusion: Analyze flow of liquid from points A, B, and C through baffles to determine which container D or E the liquid will end up in.
Image shows three liquid release points at the top (A, B, C), several baffle obstacles in the middle section, two containers at the bottom (D and E).
Liquid will flow downward from A, B, and C, encountering baffles that redirect its path before flowing into container D or E.
Liquid from A will flow downward and slightly to the right based on the orange strip's angle.
Liquid from A will encounter the brown diagonal baffle, redirecting it further to the right.
After deflection, liquid from A likely continues downward and to the right.
Liquid from A would flow toward container D (left yellow container).
Liquid from B will flow downward and to the right following the yellow diagonal strip.
Liquid from B will likely encounter the red horizontal baffle, slowing its descent.
After passing the red baffle, liquid from B will continue downward.
Liquid from B may interact with the gray horizontal baffle lower down.
Liquid from B would most likely flow into container E (right green container).
Liquid from C will flow downward and to the left based on the orientation of the orange strip.
Liquid from C would likely encounter the white horizontal baffle.
After passing the white baffle, liquid from C continues downward toward the right section.
Liquid from C would most likely flow into container E (right green container).
Liquid from point A will flow into container D; liquid from points B and C will flow into container E.
